abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social Investment Fund
            Project for Ukraine were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was substantial, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a) try to
            maintain Bank staff continuity during project design and
            implementation to avoid the loss of institutional memory and
            to maintain a close relationship with the client; b) do not
            include policy components in investment projects carried out
            by one agency which are the responsibility of other
            agencies; c) ensure early, realistic, and professional
            arrangements for impact evaluation; d) do not underestimate
            the need for early, substantial, and quality beneficiary
            community and agency training; e) even in quite traditional
            and centralized government systems, community-based micro
            project processing leads to community confidence building
            and, thus, more successful and sustainable outputs; f)
            purely technical agencies such as Ukraine Social Investment
            Fund (USIF) can play a useful role as inter-agency
            coordinators, but policy implementation is then up to the
            responsible line agencies; and g) delivery capacities for
            social services such as USIF are always relevant but they
            should be operationally efficient and flexible enough to
            shrink in times of economic prosperity and expand as needed
            during a crisis.

repnme.cdata!:
Social sphere : concentrating efforts on
            hot spots

abstracts.cdata!:
How to alleviate the impact of market
            transformations on the most vulnerable strata of the
            population? What, in general, a new strategy and social
            protection mechanisms should be in Ukraine? These questions
            have been for quite some time in the focus of great
            attention of the World Bank experts. The World Bank fist
            project in this area - the social protection support project
            (April 1997 - June 2000) had a rather modest budget of
            United States (U.S.) 3 million dollars, but it had a
            considerable social effect. This will improve the
            administering of the program of the public housing and
            utilities subsidies (PHUSP), which was in force at that time
            in Ukraine and caused many complaints due to cumbersome
            (non-automated) system of processing applications, lack of
            experience among the staff, absence of operational
            communication between relevant local and regional agencies
            and the ministry of labor and social policy of Ukraine. The
            next project - the social investment fund project - approved
            by the Board of Executive Directors of the World Bank on
            December 4, 2001, is, perhaps, one of the most successful
            projects today. It is expected that during the six years of
            this joint Ukraine-World Bank activities, over 500 micro
            projects can be implemented aimed at supporting the
            residents of poor or depressed areas, citizens with specific
            problems, children from unhappy families, and the like. And
            at the national level, it is necessary to refine the
            principles of providing such poverty-targeted assistance and
            self-aid by involving the public at large in these
            activities. In December 2002, the Board of Executive
            Directors of the World Bank approved yet another important
            project - tuberculosis (TB) and acquired immunodeficiency
            syndrome (AIDS) epidemic control project for Ukraine.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Investment Fund Project will
            assist, and support the reform of social protection, through
            the development of innovative quality, and cost-effective
            social, and communal services, as per the following
            components. First, access to basic social, and communal
            services will be provided to improve living conditions of
            the target population, by empowering communities, and
            vulnerable groups in decision-making processes, and informed
            social services policies. This will be achieved through the
            financing of community-based services micro-projects, and
            targeted social-care services micro-projects. Second,
            assistance to the Government in social protection reform
            will be provided, particularly, for the preparation of a
            social care reform strategy. This will be achieved by
            strengthening the ministries of Labor and Social Policy
            (MLSP), and of Finance (MOF) capacity to formulate, monitor,
            and evaluate social care services policies, including the
            definition, and implementation of social care service
            financing, and contracting systems. Similarly, the regional
            authorities' capacity will also be strengthened, which
            should include professional training of social workers.
            Third, project management, and monitoring and evaluation,
            should ensure the efficient implementation of the project,
            through institutional support to the Ukrainian Social
            Investment Fund (USIF) Executive Office.
